awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Soil organic carbon dynamics in response to long-term ecological changes in drylands: an integrated program for carbon cycle research and enhancing climate change literacy
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the consequences and controls of changes in the global carbon cycle is critical to both science and society. Equally crucial to society is an informed public that is able to respond to the societal challenges of climate change with sound scientific knowledge. This project is an integrated research and teaching program that will enhance understanding of the controls over the storage of carbon in dryland soils, and implement educational initiatives to enhance ecological and climate literacy in rural southern New Mexico.  Drylands are extremely important in the global carbon cycle: they account for a large proportion of global land area, and widespread changes in land cover and disturbances in these areas may strongly affect soil carbon pools.  Soil carbon dynamics are particularly poorly understood in drylands, where controls may be distinctly different from those in better-studied, less dry systems due to differences in plant inputs, vegetation cover, disturbance regimes, and climate.  A suite of new analytical techniques will be used to assess the sources and stability of soil carbon pools in drylands. These techniques will be used to address three questions: 1) How do changes in above- and belowground plant inputs affect dryland soil carbon content and stability?  2) How do differences in historical land management and vegetation affect soil carbon?  3) How do soil disturbances and vegetation change caused by desert rodents affect soil carbon content and stability?  Together, these studies will provide important information about current and future soil carbon dynamics and their feedback to the climate system.  

Educational outreach is a central focus of this project.  Early exposure to scientific ideas in children is vital for stimulating interest in science and laying the foundation for scientific literacy.  As such, educational initiatives in this project will focus on enhancing ecological and climate literacy in elementary-level students and teachers.  An inquiry based elementary curriculum focused on desert ecology and climate change will be developed, field-tested, and disseminated.  To further enhance elementary education, courses will be developed for teachers on the use of innovative technological tools to engage students in ecosystem science. Elementary curriculum development and field testing will provide support to an after-school program in a high-poverty school district with high minority enrollment. Climate change literacy in the local community will be enhanced through curriculum dissemination and teacher education courses and workshops.

por.por_cntn:
Rising atmospheric CO2 concentration is one of the most critical issues faced by society today. Accurate predictions of future atmospheric CO2, and hence future climate, requires a comprehensive understanding of global carbon (C) cycle dynamics. Equally crucial to society is an informed public that is able to respond to climate change with prudent public policy decisions. This grant helped develop an integrated research and teaching program that enhanced understanding of soil organic carbon (SOC) dynamics and turnover in drylands in the context of changes in land cover and dominant consumers and implemented educational initiatives to enhance ecological and climate literacy in New Mexico, Oregon, Arizona, and Namibia.

 

Intellectual Merit:

SOC is major component of the global C cycle, accounting for more C than atmospheric and terrestrial biomass pools combined. Drylands (arid and semi-arid systems) are particularly important in the global C cycle because they account for a large proportion of global land area and plant production, and also because widespread changes in land cover and disturbances in these areas may alter fluxes in and out of SOC pools. Studies suggest that woody encroachment, an increase in woody plant cover, enhances C sequestration in plant and SOC pools. Less clear, however, are the dynamics of these SOC pools.

 

A series of field and laboratory experiments explored factors that influence stabilization of C in dryland soils. Historical brush management treatments at several drylands in the western US were used to assess long-term degradation of SOC pools following brush management. Soil C pools, stable isotopes, mineralization studies, and plant biopolymers indicate decadal time scale loss of much of the shrub-derived SOC. However, small but persistent pools of shrub-derived SOC remained for >60 years after shrub removal, indicating the possibility that even sandy, dryland soils can stabilize measurable SOC. Studies of small mammal impacts on soil processes indicate spatially-discrete impacts on SOC, with elevated SOC patches apparently a consequence of animal modification of plant litter input quantity and quality and microclimate modification. Precipitation gradients and laboratory studies were used to explore rainfall impacts on SOC pools and processes. Soil organic carbon was generally positively related to precipitation across in Australia, although changes in vegetation cover drove landscape-scale SOC to a greater extent than precipitation alone. Short-term mechanistic studies indicate that controls over soil respiration in drylands are affected by rainfall pulse size and frequency more than cumulative precipitation. To extend this work into the future, a long-term manipulative field experiment was established to test how altered inputs of grass and shrub litter alter soil C properties on decadal time scales. Although originally planned as a single-site manipulation, this project launched the Dryland-Detrital Input and Removal (D-DIRT) Network. D-DIRT was established at three sites, with active planning by collaborators to establish additional sites in the near future. Results follow four years of treatment indicate altered microbial use of soil C substrates, suggesting long-term impacts of litter inputs on soil biological processes and subsequent SOC stabilization. The existence of a collaborative network across diverse dryland sites promises to extend this work far into the future. This research will provide important information about how dryland SOC pools may respond to future changes in land cover and disturbance regimes. Given the importance of drylands in the global C cycle, this information is crucial for improving predictive models of atmospheric CO2 concentrations.

Broader Impacts:

The study provided research training opportunities for students at New Mexico State University and Arizona State University. There were 31 undergraduates, four graduate students, and four postdoctoral scholars involved in the project. Two visiting scientists from China participated in the research.   

Successful collaborations with science educators have set the stage for career-long integration of research and public education for the project PI. Collaborations with the Asombro Institute for Science Education led to translation of project findings into several different hands-on, inquiry-driven classroom activities that were field tested and delivered to classrooms in southern New Mexico (9497 students participated in these programs from 2012-2017; Throop delivered programs to 55 students in South Africa).

Research Experiences for Teachers high school teacher Keska Kemper (Cleveland High School, Portland, OR) participated in field research in Arizona and learned GIS skills to quantify land cover change. She worked with Throop to develop hands-on classroom activities exploring vegetation change, carbon cycling, and climate change. These activities were shared with other teachers at the American Geophysical Union and through Portland Public Schools. More than 500 students participated in these activities to date.

The project was opportunistically expanded to Namibia when the PI received a Fulbright award. The project supported projects of three Namibian post-graduate students, field training on carbon cycling measurements for ca. 10 additional students and 8 faculty, and 13 students in an intensive field course. Two US undergraduate students travelled to Namibia and collaborated on research.
